title: Horror German lab which tested monkeys 'may have moved to secret new location'

Concerns are growing that the German lab which tested on petrified monkeys may have moved to a secret new location.

The Green Party are worried controversial Hamburg centre Laboratory of Phramacology and Toxicology could have been relocated - and are continuing to test the animals elsewhere in an attempt to dodge investigators.

Last week's horrifying footage of monkeys screaming in pain inside a laboratory prompted calls for an urgent change to EU laws.

The distressing video was released by animal rights activists and it sparked worldwide outrage.

It also shows cats and dogs that appear to be bleeding and even dying after undergoing cruel tests.

(Image: CEN/Cruelty Free International a)

(Image: CEN/Cruelty Free International a)

Now the Green Party says they have been tipped off that testing has not been halted.

Local Green Party politician Christiane Blomeke said: "Animal activists have reported to us that dogs and monkeys have been transported elsewhere."

MirrorOnline have approached the Laboratory of Phramacology and Toxicology for comment.



Authorities are not aware of the animals being moved to a new location but a spokesman for the local authorities investigating said: "In theory, the animals can be moved without any specific ruling.

"LPT must now inform us in advance if they plan to kill animals, this should prevent animals being killed in large numbers and cover-ups of the animals being killed.

(Image: CEN/Cruelty Free International a)

"LPT also has to inform us if an animal leaves the LPT lab."

The video was secretly shot inside Laboratory of Phramacology and Toxicology (LPT) in Hamburg, by an undercover worker from organisations Soko Tierschutz and Cruelty Free International (CF)I).

The monkeys are seen crying like newborn babies while they hang from metal harnesses strapped to their necks.

(Image: CEN/Cruelty Free International a)

Friedrich Mülln from Soko Tierschutz said: "The animals were even still waggling their tails when they were being taken to be killed, the dogs were desperate for human contact.

"The worst treatment was kept for the monkeys. The macaques breed of monkeys are small, relatively light primates, which are often used for animal experiments at LPT.

"They are kept in cramped conditions in small cages. Many of the animals have developed compulsive tendencies and are seen going round in circles."

(Image: CEN/Cruelty Free International a)

Meanwhile, thousands of protesters took to the streets to protest against the animal lab.

Mulln added: "I have had goosebumps all day. Around 7,500 people took part in the demonstration and another 700 took part in a picket action in front of the lab.

"I didn't expect that many people."
